title: Manual
text: Symbo takes: Two molecules annotated proper rotation axes User-supplied information bind one another assesses feasibly two molecules assemble common geometric forms (edge-capped tetrahedrons / face-capped tetrahedrons, edge capped-cube, etc).

previous_headings: Symbo > Step 0: Setting up your R environment
title: Manual
text: Start installing: 1. R (programming language ) 2. Rstudio Desktop (development environment like Positron) 3. Rtools (collection utilities allow compile install packages github) boot editor, navigate console get ready install required R packages

previous_headings: Symbo > Step 0: Setting up your R environment
title: Manual
text: package ’ll need install symbo running (console) install symbo also dependencies.

what: Step 1: Setting up your molecular structures
title: Manual
text: Symbo expects input two mol2 files. example Iron Tripod Palladium atom. Symbo assess higher-order geometric structures two molecules can feasibly form bound together. first must inform symbo two molecules likely bind. add least 1 dummy atom molecule representing position think atom molecule bind. example ’d expect palladium bind nitrogens arm iron tripod, add dummy atom representing think exactly palladium bind. expect 3 palladiums bind 3 nitrogens iron tripod need include 1. NOTE: Please ensure dummy atom marked molecular editor. done, repeat process second molecule. example add dummy nitrogen atom binding 90 degree angles palladium. technically one dummy atom required, adding 4 make much easier annotate proper rotation axis (next step). TODO: INSERT EXAMPLE PLOTS Finally, export molecules mol2 format, boot R editor (Rstudio) open new script.

title: Manual
text: Now ’ve prepared mol2 molecules can load minto R ensure everything worked ok. loading packages run following code prevent 3D plots trying render local graphics engine instead render exclusively web based viewer. can start parsing files using read_mol() function structures package (automatically installed alongside symbo). run mol2 files replace calls system.file() string path file interest (e.g. "/Users/username/Documents/my_molecule_1.mol2") Lets investigate molecules printing summary see molecule 1 (iron tripod) contains 83 atoms, 3 dummy atoms representing palladium binding position. Task: molecule 2
code: options(rgl.useNULL=TRUE) # Load the libraries we need library(structures) # For reading mol2 files and annotating molecular structures library(chemviewR) # For visualising 3D molecular structures library(symbo) # For assessing geometrical feasibility of higher level structures  # Parse Molecules molecule1_filepath <- system.file(package = "symbo", "fe_dummies.mol2") molecule1 <- read_mol2(molecule1_filepath)  molecule2_filepath <- system.file(package = "symbo", "pd_dummies.mol2") molecule2 <- read_mol2(molecule2_filepath) #> Warning in format_atoms(atoms): Unexpected atom types found: [Pd]. Replacing #> these with 'Any' print(molecule1) #> =================== #> Chemical Molecule3D #> =================== #> Name: fe_dummies #> Atoms: 83 (3 dummy atoms) #> Bonds: 90 #> Molecule type: SMALL #> Charge type: NO_CHARGES #> ------------------- #> Symmetry Elements: 0 #> Symmetry Axes: 0 #> Symmetry Orders (Cn):  #> ------------------- #> See @atoms paramater for atom positions #> See @bonds paramater for bond positions #> See @symmetry_elements for symmetry elements

title: Manual
text: can create 3D interactive plots molecules time using plot_molecule function chemviewR (also automaticaly installed bondy).   Note learn specific function just run ?function R console. E.g. learn customise visualisation can run ?plot_molecule

title: Manual
text: Now molecules parsed, need annotate proper rotation axes symbo can use information infer potential higher-level structures might form.  Next lets annotate second molecule symmetry axes.
code: # Iron tripods have a C3 proper rotation axis.  # This axis is identical to the normal of the plane formed by our three N5 nitrogen atoms. So lets first compute this plane molecule1_plane <- molecule1 |>   filter_atoms_by_name("N5") |>   compute_plane_from_atoms()  ## Then we can create a 'ProperRotationAxis' object based on the plane_normal & centroid of the 3 N5 irons c3_axis_iron_tripod <- ProperRotationAxis(       n = 3, # Axis order; as in (Cn)       posA = molecule1_plane$centroid,       direction = molecule1_plane$normal   )  ## Annotate our molecule with this ProperRotationAxis molecule1 <- molecule1 |>   add_symmetry_element_to_molecule(c3_axis_iron_tripod)  # Visualise The plot to see if it worked plot_molecule(molecule1) # Palladium has a C4 symmetry axis. # Direction is equivalent to the normal or the plane formed by the entire molecule # (including all four dummy atoms) so lets compute that plane molecule2_plane <- molecule2 |>   compute_plane_from_atoms()  ## Then we create a 'ProperRotationAxis' object based on the plane_normal & centroid of the entire molecule c4_axis_palladium <- ProperRotationAxis(   n = 4, # Axis order; as in (Cn)   posA = molecule2_plane$centroid,    direction = molecule2_plane$normal )   # Then we annotate our molecule with this information molecule2 <- molecule2 |>   add_symmetry_element_to_molecule(c4_axis_palladium)  # Plot the molecule to make the axis is present plot_molecule(molecule2)

previous_headings: Symbo > Step 4: Specifying Binding Atoms and Running Optimisation
title: Manual
text: running optimisation now just need know binding atoms molecule. example, N5 nitrogen atoms iron tripod structure (molecule1) bind palladium atoms (Pd) molecule 2, N5 nitrogen + palladium atoms binding atoms. need specify element numbers. find can view full set atoms molecules find eleno (element number) correspond N5 nitrogen molecule1 Palladium atom molecule2.

previous_headings: Symbo > Step 4: Specifying Binding Atoms and Running Optimisation
title: Manual
text: Now just run optimisation results show, shape class evaluated, two values D: minimised sum squared distances dummy atoms molecule opposing binding atom. Formally: , distance mol1 dummy atom mol2 binding atom, distance mol2 dummy atom mol1 binding atom, evaluated optimum. : angle two dummy binding vectors: Numeric scalar (radians) giving angle vector mol1 dummy → mol1 binding atom vector mol2 dummy → mol2 binding atom, computed optimised geometry. “perfect” solution angle π (3.14 ~= 180 degrees).
code: # Specify the binding atom optimisations <- screen_molecules(   molecule1 = molecule1,   molecule2 = molecule2,    mol1_binding_atom = 7, # One of the N5 Nitrogens   mol2_binding_atom = 1  # Palladium atom ) #> ℹ Figuring out which shape classes are assessable #> ℹ Molecule 1 [fe_dummies] has [C3] #> ℹ Molecule 2 [pd_dummies] has [C4] #> ℹ Molecules [fe_dummies] and [pd_dummies] can be assessed for [1] shape class (Face-capped cube). #>  #> ── Face-capped cube ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #> ℹ Fetching the first dummy atom in each molecule #> ℹ Rotating molecules so Symmetry Axes align with target vectors #> ℹ Extracting Symmetry Axes #> ℹ Searching for optimal arrangement of molecules #> ℹ Running optimisation (this may take a moment) ... #> ℹ Optimisation finished! Compiling results ...  # View result summary print(optimisations) #> ================================ #> Optimisation Result Collection #> ================================ #> Shape Classes Evaluated: 1 #> -> Face-capped cube (D: 0.000019 | A: 3.139092)

text: Summarise results convenient html report.

what: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: [!WARNING] package early development yet ready use symbo takes two molecular structures assesses (based symmetry properties) geometric feasability forming different higher-order structures (e.g. tetrahedral / edge-capped cube / face-capped cube / etc.)

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: can install development version symbo like :

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Please see manual.

what: Optimisation result for two aligned molecules — OptimisationResult
title: Optimisation result for two aligned molecules — OptimisationResult
text: OptimisationResult S7  object stores outcome geometric optimisation used align two structures::Molecule3D objects. records optimised geometries molecule, optimisation objective, key geometric parameters (angles, slides axes) bookkeeping information returned optimiser.

title: Optimisation result for two aligned molecules — OptimisationResult
code: OptimisationResult(   shapeclass = "NotSpecified",   mol1 = structures::Molecule3D(),   mol2 = structures::Molecule3D(),   min_sum_of_squared_distance = NaN,   angle_between_dummy_binding_vectors = NaN,   mol1_phi = NaN,   mol2_phi = NaN,   mol1_slide = NaN,   mol2_slide = NaN,   mol1_axis = c(NaN, NaN, NaN),   mol2_axis = c(NaN, NaN, NaN),   n_calls_to_fn = 0,   n_calls_to_gr = 0,   convergence = NA_real_,   message = NA_character_,   hessian = 2 )

title: Optimisation result for two aligned molecules — OptimisationResult
text: mol1 structures::Molecule3D object giving optimised coordinates first molecule. Defaults empty Molecule3D() instance. mol2 structures::Molecule3D object giving optimised coordinates second molecule. Defaults empty Molecule3D() instance.

title: Optimisation result for two aligned molecules — OptimisationResult
text: new OptimisationResult S7 object supplied molecules fields initialised type-appropriate defaults.

title: Optimisation result for two aligned molecules — OptimisationResult
text: class following properties: mol1 structures::Molecule3D object representing first input molecule geometrically optimised form (.e., applying optimal rotation/translation minimises min_sum_of_squared_distance). mol2 structures::Molecule3D object representing second input molecule geometrically optimised form. min_sum_of_squared_distance Numeric scalar giving minimised sum squared distances dummy atoms molecule opposing binding atom. Formally: \(d_1^2 + d_2^2\), \(d_1\) distance mol1 dummy atom mol2 binding atom, \(d_2\) distance mol2 dummy atom mol1 binding atom, evaluated optimum. angle_between_dummy_binding_vectors Numeric scalar (radians) giving angle vector mol1 dummy \(\\) mol1 binding atom vector mol2 dummy \(\\) mol2 binding atom, computed optimised geometry. “perfect” solution angle \(\pi\) (180 degrees). mol1_phi Numeric scalar (radians): optimal rotation angle applied mol1 mol1_axis obtain geometrically optimal configuration. mol2_phi Numeric scalar (radians): optimal rotation angle applied mol2 mol2_axis. mol1_slide Numeric scalar giving optimal distance translate mol1 along mol1_axis (“slide” along axis) optimal configuration. mol2_slide Numeric scalar giving optimal distance translate mol2 along mol2_axis. mol1_axis Numeric length-3 vector describing Cartesian direction symmetry axis mol1 rotated along slid optimisation. mol2_axis Numeric length-3 vector describing corresponding axis mol2. n_calls_to_fn Numeric scalar giving number calls objective function (fn) made optimiser. n_calls_to_gr Numeric scalar giving number calls gradient function (gr) made optimiser (applicable). convergence Numeric scalar convergence code, typically matching codes returned stats::optim(). example: 0 – successful completion (method-dependent). 1 – iteration limit (maxit) reached. 10 – degeneracy Nelder–Mead simplex. 51 – warning method "L-BFGS-B" (see message). 52 – error method "L-BFGS-B" (see message). See documentation optimisation routine exact meanings. message Character scalar giving additional information returned optimiser (e.g. warnings, diagnostic messages). May NA_character_ message available. hessian Numeric object (typically symmetric matrix) giving estimate Hessian solution, available. usually Hessian unconstrained problem, even box constraints active. optimisation run without requesting Hessian, property set NaN. Assigning NULL hessian also store NaN internally.

title: Optimisation result for two aligned molecules — OptimisationResult
text: Instances OptimisationResult usually created internally higher-level alignment / docking routines, returned structured record optimisation outcome given shape class binding mode.

title: Optimisation result for two aligned molecules — OptimisationResult
code: # (Pseudo-example; real usage would normally be through an optimiser) res <- OptimisationResult(   mol1 = structures::Molecule3D(),   mol2 = structures::Molecule3D() ) res@min_sum_of_squared_distance <- 0.12 res@n_calls_to_fn <- 35  print(res) #> ================================ #> Optimisation Result #> ================================ #> Shape Classes: NotSpecified #> Minimised Sum of Squared Distance: 0.120000 #> Minimised Angle (pi = perfect): NaN #> Convergence: NA

title: Collection of optimisation results — OptimisationResultCollection
text: OptimisationResultCollection S7 container object stores one OptimisationResult objects, typically corresponding different shape classes binding modes evaluated single alignment / docking run. provides: list-like slot @optimisations containing individual optimisation results; read-@shapeclasses property extracts shapeclass field contained result. convenience base::.data.frame() method provided key summary quantities (distance, angle, rotations, slides, axes) can inspected compared tabular form.

title: Collection of optimisation results — OptimisationResultCollection
Collection of optimisation results — OptimisationResultCollection
text: optimisations list OptimisationResult objects. Defaults empty list.

title: Collection of optimisation results — OptimisationResultCollection
text: new OptimisationResultCollection S7 object containing supplied optimisation results.

title: Collection of optimisation results — OptimisationResultCollection
text: class following properties: optimisations list OptimisationResult objects. list may empty. validator enforces every element list valid OptimisationResult; otherwise error raised. shapeclasses Character vector (read-) giving shapeclass value element @optimisations, order. computed fly via getter set directly.

title: Collection of optimisation results — OptimisationResultCollection
text: Instances OptimisationResultCollection usually constructed higher-level routines evaluate multiple shape classes. shape class produces OptimisationResult, collected single object printing, summarising, coercion data frame.

title: Collection of optimisation results — OptimisationResultCollection
code: # Create a couple of dummy optimisation results res1 <- OptimisationResult(shapeclass = "shapeA") res2 <- OptimisationResult(shapeclass = "shapeB")  # Combine into a collection coll <- OptimisationResultCollection(   optimisations = list(res1, res2) ) #> Error in OptimisationResultCollection(optimisations = list(res1, res2)): argument "mol1_not_optimised" is missing, with no default  # Print summary coll #> Error: object 'coll' not found  # Coerce to data.frame for further analysis df <- as.data.frame(coll) #> Error: object 'coll' not found df$shapeclass #> Error in df$shapeclass: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable

text: Create report summarising results screen

title: Create a report summarising results of screen — create_summary_report
Create a report summarising results of screen — create_summary_report

title: Create a report summarising results of screen — create_summary_report
text: invisibly returns NULL (function run side effects)

what: Find Optimal Position of molecules — find_optimal_position
title: Find Optimal Position of molecules — find_optimal_position
text: Find Optimal Position molecules

title: Find Optimal Position of molecules — find_optimal_position
code: find_optimal_position(   mol1,   mol2,   mol1_axis,   mol2_axis,   mol1_dummy_eleno,   mol2_dummy_eleno,   mol1_binding_atom,   mol2_binding_atom,   method = c("Nelder-Mead", "BFGS", "CG", "L-BFGS-B", "SANN", "Brent"),   lower = -Inf,   upper = Inf,   control = list(),   hessian = FALSE )

title: Find Optimal Position of molecules — find_optimal_position
text: mol1 structures::Molecule3D() proper rotation axis transformed lies mol1_axis. mol2 structures::Molecule3D() proper rotation axis transformed lies mol2_axis. mol1_axis, mol2_axis symmetry axis transform molecules searching geometrically optimal solution mol1_dummy_eleno, mol2_dummy_eleno eleno dummy atom representing binding atom opposing molecule mol1_binding_atom atom expect bind molecule2 (integer representing element number .k.eleno). mol2_binding_atom atom expect bind molecule1 (integer representing element number .k.eleno). method, lower, upper, control, hessian optimisation algorith configuration. See stats::optim() details.

title: Find Optimal Position of molecules — find_optimal_position
text: list including: mol1_optimal: structures::Molecule3D() object representing input molecule geometrically optimised minimiise min_sum_of_squared_distance mol2_optimal: structures::Molecule3D() object representing input molecule geometrically optimised minimiise min_sum_of_squared_distance min_sum_of_squared_distance: Minimised sum squared distance dummy atoms molecule opposing atom binding atom. Formally: d1^2 + d2^2 d1 = distance mol1 dummy mol2 binding atom d2 = distance mol2 dummy mol1 binding atom angle_between_dummy_binding_vectors: angle (radians) vectors mol1 dummy atom -> mol1 bonding atom mol2 dummy atom -> mol2 bonding atom. value calculated geometrically optimised solution, perfect solution found equal pi (180 degrees) mol1_phi: optimal angle (radians) mol1 rotated mol1_axis give geometrically optimal solution mol2_phi: optimal angle (radians) mol2 rotated mol2_axis give geometrically optimal solution mol1_slide: optimal distance slide mol1 along mol1_axis give geometrically optimal solution. mol2_slide: optimal distance slide mol2 along mol2_axis give geometrically optimal solution. mol1_axis: length-3 vector describing xyz direction symmetry axis mol1 transformed around mol2_axis: length-3 vector describing xyz direction symmetry axis mol2 transformed around n_calls_to_fn: number calls optimisation function (fn) n_calls_to_gr: number calls gradient function (gr) convergence: convergence value. 1 indicates iteration limit maxit reached. 10 indicates degeneracy Nelder–Mead simplex. 51 indicates warning "L-BFGS-B" method; see component message details. 52 indicates error "L-BFGS-B" method; see component message details. message: character string giving additional information returned optimizer, NULL. hessian: argument hessian true. symmetric matrix giving estimate Hessian solution found. Note Hessian unconstrained problem even box constraints active.

what: Get assessable polyhedral geometries from symmetry axis orders — get_assessable_shapeclasses
title: Get assessable polyhedral geometries from symmetry axis orders — get_assessable_shapeclasses
text: Given two sets unique proper rotation axis orders two molecules, function returns subset geometries can assessed symmetries.

title: Get assessable polyhedral geometries from symmetry axis orders — get_assessable_shapeclasses
Get assessable polyhedral geometries from symmetry axis orders — get_assessable_shapeclasses
text: molecule1_axes numeric character vector unique proper rotation axis orders present molecule 1 (e.g. c(3, 4)). molecule2_axes numeric character vector unique proper rotation axis orders present molecule 2 (e.g. c(2)). mapping data.frame describing symmetry-axis combinations correspond geometries. must contain least columns ShapeClass, Axis1_order, Axis2_order; additional columns (e.g. Notes) preserved output. Defaults symbo::ShapeClass_axis_map.

title: Get assessable polyhedral geometries from symmetry axis orders — get_assessable_shapeclasses
text: data.frame containing assessable geometries given supplied axes. includes columns mapping, plus: treat_molecule2_as_1: logical; FALSE ShapeClass assessable forward orientation (mol1 -> Axis1, mol2 -> Axis2), TRUE assessable molecules swapped. geometries assessable, empty data.frame returned.

title: Get assessable polyhedral geometries from symmetry axis orders — get_assessable_shapeclasses
text: Geometries matched two orientations: Forward: molecule1_axes supply Axis1_order molecule2_axes supply Axis2_order. Swapped: molecule2_axes supply Axis1_order molecule1_axes supply Axis2_order. geometries assessable swapped orientation, treat_molecule2_as_1 set TRUE indicate downstream code treat molecule 2 molecule 1.

title: Get assessable polyhedral geometries from symmetry axis orders — get_assessable_shapeclasses
code: # Suppose molecule 1 has C3 and C4, molecule 2 has C2: get_assessable_shapeclasses(molecule1_axes = c(3, 4),                           molecule2_axes = 2) #>   mol1_axis mol2_axis flipped               ShapeClass Axis1 Axis2 Axis1x #> 1         3         2   FALSE                       D3     3     2      1 #> 2         3         2   FALSE  Edge-capped tetrahedron     3     2      1 #> 3         3         2   FALSE         Edge-capped cube     3     2      1 #> 4         3         2   FALSE Edge-capped dodecahedron     3     2      1 #> 5         4         2   FALSE                       D4     4     2      1 #> 6         4         2   FALSE   Edge-capped octahedron     4     2      0 #>   Axis1y Axis1z Axis2x Axis2y   Axis2z Notes assessable #> 1      0      0      0      1 0.000000             TRUE #> 2      1      1      0      0 1.618034             TRUE #> 3      1      1      1      0 1.000000             TRUE #> 4      1      1      0      0 1.618034             TRUE #> 5      0      0      0      1 0.000000             TRUE #> 6      0      1      1      0 1.000000             TRUE  # If molecule 1 only has C2 and molecule 2 has C3, some geometries # (e.g. edge-capped dodecahedron) are only assessable by swapping: get_assessable_shapeclasses(molecule1_axes = 2,                           molecule2_axes = 3) #>   mol1_axis mol2_axis flipped               ShapeClass Axis1 Axis2 Axis1x #> 1         3         2    TRUE                       D3     3     2      1 #> 2         3         2    TRUE  Edge-capped tetrahedron     3     2      1 #> 3         3         2    TRUE         Edge-capped cube     3     2      1 #> 4         3         2    TRUE Edge-capped dodecahedron     3     2      1 #>   Axis1y Axis1z Axis2x Axis2y   Axis2z Notes assessable #> 1      0      0      0      1 0.000000             TRUE #> 2      1      1      0      0 1.618034             TRUE #> 3      1      1      1      0 1.000000             TRUE #> 4      1      1      0      0 1.618034             TRUE

what: Screen molecules for valid Shape classes — screen_molecules
title: Screen molecules for valid Shape classes — screen_molecules
text: Screens pair molecules find geometrically optimal configuration produce shapeclasses

title: Screen molecules for valid Shape classes — screen_molecules
code: screen_molecules(   molecule1,   molecule2,   mol1_binding_atom,   mol2_binding_atom,   method = c("Nelder-Mead", "BFGS", "CG", "L-BFGS-B", "SANN", "Brent"),   lower = -Inf,   upper = Inf,   control = list(),   hessian = FALSE )

title: Screen molecules for valid Shape classes — screen_molecules
text: molecule1 structures::Molecule3D() object symmetry axes annotated dummy atoms representing mol2_binding_atom might bind. molecule2 structures::Molecule3D() object symmetry axes annotated dummy atoms representing mol1_binding_atom might bind. mol1_binding_atom atom expect bind molecule2 (integer representing element number .k.eleno). mol2_binding_atom atom expect bind molecule1 (integer representing element number .k.eleno). method, lower, upper, control, hessian optimisation algorith configuration. See stats::optim() details.

title: Screen molecules for valid Shape classes — screen_molecules
text: OptimisationResultCollection object.
